summary: This document appears to be an internal email or memo from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, discussing a potential proffer session with a client (likely a witness or associate) regarding the Epstein case. It details considerations about the legal protections of the discussion under Rule 410, the scope of topics (background, scheduling, abuse), and the possibility of resolving the matter.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Author of the correspondence, discussing the terms and considerations for a proffer session with a client/witness in the Epstein matter.

events.title: Discussion of Proffer Agreement
events.description: Prosecutors discussed with defense counsel the terms and legal protections (Rule 410) for a potential proffer session with a client, including the scope of discussion (background, scheduling, abuse) and a waiver limited to proceedings brought by their Office.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: Prosecutors were negotiating a proffer agreement with a client/witness on November 25, 2019, viewing it as a step toward resolving the matter.
The discussion centered on ensuring the proffer was protected under Federal Rule of Evidence 410, which governs the inadmissibility of withdrawn pleas and offers.
The witness's proposed waiver of protections was to be limited solely to criminal proceedings brought by the U.S. Attorney's Office.
The intended topics for the proffer included the individual's background, upbringing, employment, and crucially, 'how she went about scheduling, as well as the abuse'.
Prosecutors noted they do not ordinarily treat investigative interviews or innocence proffers as covered by Rule 410, but were checking with supervisors about making an exception in this case.
